tool.name: FROGSSTAT DESeq2 Visualisation
tool.description: to extract and visualise differentially abundant ASVs or functions

param.name: analysis
param.label: Type of analysis
param.help: Type of data to perform the differential analysis. ASV: DESeq2 is run on the ASV abundance table. FUNCTION: DESeq2 is run on predicted function abundance table from FROGSFUNC_2_function tool.

param.label: Data object (format: data.RData)
param.help: For ASV: asv_data.Rdata from FROGSSTAT_Phyloseq_Import_Data tool - For FUNCTION: function_data.Rdata from FROGSSTAT_DESeq2_Preprocess tool.

param.label: DESeq2 object (format: dds.RData)
param.help: This is the result of FROGSSTAT_DESeq2_Preprocess tool asv_dds.Rdata or function_dds.Rdata

param.label: Experimental variable
param.help: The factor that could have an effect on ASV/FUNCTION abundances. Ex : Treatment

param.name: vartType_selected
param.label: The experimental variable is it quantitative or qualitative?
param.help: If qualitative, choose 2 conditions to compare

param.label: Condition 1 considered as reference
param.help: One condition of the experimental variable (e.g. with)

param.label: Condition 2 to be compared to the reference
param.help: Another condition of the experimental variable (e.g. without)

param.label: Adjusted p-value threshold
param.help: Threshold used for statistical significance of the differentially abundant ASV/FUNCTION analysis

tool.help:
@HELP_LOGO@
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
What it does
Launch one Rmarkdown Script to visualise the DESeq2 results.
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
Inputs/Outputs
.. class:: h3
Input
**-Data object-** (format data.Rdata): One *phyloseq* object stored in a Rdata file. This file is the result of :
1. for **ASV**: asv.dds.Rdata from FROGSSTAT_Phyloseq_Import_Data tool 2. for **FUNCTION**: DESeq2_preprocess_tool output for FUNCTION parameter.
**-DESeq2 object-** (format dds.Rdata): A DESeq2 dataset (dds) stored in Rdata file. This file is the result of FROGSSTAT_DESeq2_preprocess tool.
.. class:: h3
Ouput
**-2 TSV files-** - ipath_under.tsv - ipath_over.tsv To visualise and explore metabolic pathways with `IPATH3 website <https://pathways.embl.de/>`_ , use the two files **ipath_under.tsv** and **ipath_over.tsv** as inputs.
**-html file-** (format `HTML <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML>`_): visualisation of *Differential Abundance* of ASV or FUNCTIONS depending on the case.
The html file contains Table, Pie Chart, MA plot, Volcano plot and Heatmap plot. If the experimental variable is qualitative, only samples corresponding to the 2 compared conditions are shown in the Heatmap. Otherwise, samples are sorted in increasing order of the experimental variable.
* Table containing the differentially abundant ASVs.
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_table.png :height: 448 :width: 641
* Pie Chart, MA plot and Volcano plot
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_pieChart.png :height: 576 :width: 768
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_MA_plot.png :height: 480 :width: 672
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_Volcano_plot.png :height: 506 :width: 633
* Heatmap plot corresponding to the differentially abundant ASVs.
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_heatmap_plot.png :height: 576 :width: 768
* Differentially abundant functions visualized with iPath 3 (FUNCTION analysis only).
.. image:: FROGS_DESeq2_html_ipath.png :height: 720 :width: 584
.. class:: infomark page-header h2
How it works ?
Based on the variable you precise to construct the model in FROGSSTAT DESeq2 Preprocess, this tool will construct table and graphs to visualise differentially abundant ASV or functions between condition of the selected variables.
You may first precise the variable used to construct the model during the FROGSSTAT DESeq Preprocess step. If you precised variable with a confounding factor (a second variable), you may choose between one of the variables, but remember that you will see the result of this variable corrected by the confounding factor (and reversely) not just the selected variable itself.
If the variable is qualitative (ex: variable treatment is define by two conditions : treatment1, treatment2, control), you must specify 2 conditions to compare (e.g. treatment1 vs treatment2 or treatment1 vs control, ...).
